title: 109_s3981
content: The Act may be cited as the "Citizen Petition Fairness and Accuracy Act of 2006" and pertains to citizen petitions and petitions for stay of agency action. The "Citizen Petition Fairness and Accuracy Act of 2006" amends Section 505(j)(5) of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act to require that any petition submitted under specific regulations must include all relevant information, be factually supported, not submitted for improper purposes, and not contain false statements. The Secretary is mandated to investigate any complaints regarding such petitions. The Secretary may impose penalties, suspend, or permanently revoke the authority of a petitioner who submits a petition that does not comply with requirements, is for an improper purpose, or contains false statements under specific regulations. Penalties may include a civil penalty of up to $1,000,000, suspension of petition submission authority for up to 10 years, and permanent revocation of petition submission authority. The Secretary may impose penalties, suspend, or permanently revoke the authority of a petitioner who submits a petition that does not comply with requirements, is for an improper purpose, or contains false statements under specific regulations. Penalties may include a civil penalty of up to $1,000,000, suspension of petition submission authority for up to 10 years, and permanent revocation of petition submission authority. If enforcement action is taken, the petition will be referred to the Federal Trade Commission for further action. The Secretary will consider various factors in determining the appropriate enforcement action and penalties. The Secretary may impose penalties, suspend, or permanently revoke the authority of a petitioner for improperly submitted petitions, including false, misleading, or fraudulent claims. Aggrieved persons can request an investigation for enforcement action if they believe a petition is false or submitted for an improper purpose. Violators may face civil penalties. The Secretary may impose penalties for violations of petition submission rules, with a 6-month deadline for final agency action on petitions. If no action is taken within this period, the petition is deemed denied. Regulations may be established to determine enforcement actions on petitions.
